title: Corn Bread Recipe
content:
**CORN BREAD** (Makes 12 servings) 1 cup ALBERS Yellow Corn Meal 1 cup all-purpose flour 1/4 cup granulated sugar 1 tablespoon baking powder teaspoon salt cup milk 1/3 cup vegetable oil 1 egg, lightly beaten **COMBINE** cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in medium bowl. Combine milk, oil and egg in small bowl; mix well. ADD milk mixture to flour mixture; stir just until blended. Pour into greased 8-inch-square pan.

BAKE in preheated 400°F. oven for 20 to 25 minutes or until wooden pick inserted in center comes out clean. Serve warm. NOTE: Recipe may be doubled. Use greased 13 x 9-inch pan; bake as above. title: Rosette Cookies Recipe
content:
- . To Fry: Place approximately 2" of oil in deep fryer or saucepan. Heat to 375". Securely attach two molds to handle and immerse in hot oil until thoroughly heated. Lift iron out and shake off excess oil (or blot on paper toweling). Dip iron into batter only to the depth of the molds. Avoid getting batter on top of molds. Immerse molds into hot oil, covering completely. When foamy bubbling stops, or Rosettes are a delicate brown, lift iron out, allowing excess oil to drip back into fryer. To remove Rosette, gently tap on top of mold with a wooden spoon. Before making additional Rosettes, reheat iron as necessary. (Iron must be hot!)
- If excess batter adheres to top of mold, fry as usual, then gently remove excess with knife for easier release.
- If batter will not adhere to molds, oil may be either too hot or too cold. Check with thermometer and adjust accordingly.
- If first Rosette Cookies are not crisp, thin batter with a little milk. Also check the temperature of oil and molds.
- Cool, with the more open side down, on rack or paper towelling.
- To store: Layer cooled cookies nor more than 3 deep in air-tight container. May be frozen.

title: Egg Recipes
content:
Eggehilada: Scramble eggs and spoon down the center of a tortilla. Roll up the tortilla, top it off with enchilada sauce and a drift of sour cream. Scatter some green onion on for a finishing touch. Simple and centsible.

The Prairie Dog: Fry an egg sunnyside up and, while it's frying, toast a split English muffin half and grill a split frank. Layer it all with a slice of cheese and then enjoy.

The Eggburger: Scramble an egg or two, or fry them over easy, then serve on a burger bun. Top with your choice of the workscheese, mushrooms, lettuce, tomato, onion, bacon, catsup, olives, almost anything. A mansized meal for mini-money.

Quiche: follow a basic recipe and vary it anyway you like. The greatest thing about a quiche is that it is a perfect vehicle for leftovers. You can use chopped cooked chicken, fish, ham, or almost any shredded cheeses. Or chopped cooked vegetables such as green beans, carrots, broccoli, asparagus, cauliflower,  $potatoes -$ 

The possibilities are endless.

title: Chocolate Truffle Recipe
content:
In heavy 2-quart saucepan combine chopped chocolate, half the whipping cream, and margarine. Cook and stir over low heat 10 minutes or till chocolate melts. Remove from heat; gradually stir about half the hot mixture into beaten yolks. Return yolk mixture to pan. Cook and stir over medium heat 2 minutes more or till thickened; remove from heat. Stir in remaining cream.

Chill about 1 hour or till mixture is completely cool and smooth, stirring occasionally; transfer to Small Mixing Bowl. Beat with an electric mixer on medium speed 2 minutes or till slightly fluffy. Apply Seal; chill 15 minutes or till mixture holds its shape. For each truffle, drop a heaping tablespoon of the mixture onto a waxed paper-lined baking sheet. Chill 15 minutes or till firm. Do not overchill. Roll each mound into a 11/2-inch ball. Chill 20 minutes more.

title: Taco Quiche
content:
**TACO QUICHE** Filling: 8 corn tortillas (soft) 2 lbs. lean ground beef 1 purple Spanish onion. chopped 1 clove garlic, pressed 1 teaspoon chili powder <sup>1</sup>4 teaspoon EACH: ground cumin, thyme, salt <sup>1/2</sup> teaspoon oregano 1 lb. shredded Monterey **Jack cheese** Custard: **6eggs** 2 cups milk Toppings: 1 small head lettuce, shredded 2 tomatoes, sliced

1lar avocado, sliced  $\frac{1}{2}$  pint sour cream olives for garnish chili salsa, optional

Preheat oven to 350°F. Lightly grease an extra large quiche dish (or a 9"x13" pan or two 9" pie pans). Line with tortillas, tearing them to fit, if necessary. Brown ground beef and onion, then add spices. Pour into pan(s). Top with shredded cheese. Beat eggs and milk together and pour over all. Bake approximately 1 hour or until custard is set. While still warm, spread sour cream, then tomatoes and avocados, ending with lettuce and olives. Pass the salsa. Serves 8.

title: Mulled Christmas Wine
content: MULLED CHRISTMAS WINE 1 lemon 10 whole cloves **Cinnamon** sticks 1/2 cup sugar 1 bottle (4/5 quart) dry red wine (Burgundy, for example) Using a sharp knife, cut peel off lemon in a continuous spiral. title: Basic Adobo Recipe
content:
Dear Kowolik,

Hello! It's me, Glenn Seavey, your Hawaiian Sales Consultant at Larry Genere Ford. As you probably know, I am originally from Hawaii. I love the food and the culture and would like to share this love with you. The recipe below for Basic Adobo is one of my favorites. It is a Phillipino dish that is very easy to make and "ono" good.

Basic Adobo Ingredients: 3 1b. chicken thighs or 3 1b. pork butt 1/2 cup vinegar 1/4 cup soy sauce 3 cloves of garlic 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/4 teaspoon peppercorns, crushed 1 bay leaf, crushed Cut chicken pieces in half if thighs are large. If using pork, cut into 1 1/2 inch pieces. In a saucepan, combine all ingredients. Let stand for 1 to 3 hours. Bring to a boil. Cover, lower heat, and simmer for 30 minutes (45) minutes for pork). Remove cover and simmer 15 more minutes or until liquid evaporates and chicken/pork is lightly browned. Makes 6 servings.

I would recommend preparing some white rice as a side dish. Please call me after you prepare this dish and tell me what you think... or just bring a little by so I can sample your version. Enjoy!

Sincerely, Glenn Seavey Larry Geweke Ford  $530 - 821 - 2121$

title: Ham & Pineapple Kebabs
content:
Ten 8-inch bamboo skewers 1/4 cup margarine Butter Flavor Crisco 1/4 cup orange marmalade 1 tablespoon Dijon mustard

- 1. Cut or break skewers in half. Soak in water while assembling other ingredients.
- 2. Combine Butter Flavor Crisco, marmalade, and mustard in small saucepan. Heat over low until Butter Flavor Crisco is melted. Stir well. Set sauce aside.
- 3. Cut ham into 1/2-inch cubes. Cut water chestnuts in half.
- 4. Push onto skewers one piece ham, water chestnut\*, pineapple and pepper. Brush with sauce. Place in foil-lined 13x9-inch or 15x10-inch pan. Broil 4 inches from heat source several minutes. Turn Brush with remaining sauce. Broil until hot and just browning. **18 TO 20 KEBOBS**

Hors D'Oeuvre Kebobs

- 1 slice (1/2-inch thick) square cooked ham
- 1 can (8 ounces) water chestnuts
- 1 can (8 ounces) pineapple chunks
- small red or green bell pepper, cut in 3/4-inch squares

\*To prevent splitting of water chestnut, place on flat surface, gently twist skewer into center

title: Chili Pulled Pork Tostadas
content:
**TOSTADAS** 1 lb. Chili Rub Slow Cooker Pulled Pork 3-4 limes 2 tbsp. canola oil or other neutral-flavored oil 8 c. finely shredded cabbage or slaw mix 3/4 c. coarsely chopped cilantro 4/4 red onion, thinly sliced I c. sour cream 1/2 canned chipotle pepper in adobo sauce, seeded and minced

68-in. crisped corn tortillas 2 tomatoes, diced 3 radishes, cut into wedges Salt to taste

Combine 2 tbsp. lime juice with oil in large bowl; add cabbage, onion and cilantro, toss to mix. Add salt to taste. Cut remaining limes into 6 wedges each; set aside. In small bowl, combine sour cream and chipotle pepper. Salt to taste; set aside. Arrange tortillas on plates. Top with pork, slaw, sour cream mixture and tomatoes. Place lime and radish wedges alongside and serve.

Makes 6 servings

Dry rubs store on the shelf for 1 to 1 months, depending on the blend of ingredients. Not all ingredients will age at the rame rate, so the flavor of the rub may change the longer it is stored. Larger cuts of meat or whole portions of poultry and fish use about 16 cup. Depending on how the dry rub is to be used. there may be some remaining for a second use. To prevent the contains nation of remaining rub during initial use, measure only the amount of rub needed for one application in a separate dish.

title: Roasted Garlic Recipe
content:
When garlic is roasted, it becomes mild and soft enough to spread over bread or crackers. For additional herb flavor, place a sprig of fresh thyme over the cut surface of the garlic before roasting. Roasted garlic can also be used to flavor cream of potato soup. Simply roast as directed. When cool, squeeze Preparing Garlic
For Roasting the garlic from the skin into the soup and puree the entire mixture. One whole head or bulb of garlic will flavor 6 to 8 quarts of soup. Roasted Garlic 4 whole garlic heads 1/3 cup water 1/4 cup olive or vegetable oil Sliced French or Italian bread Cut the top off of each garlic head (the end that comes to a closed point) so that each clove is exposed. Place with cut side up in a small ungreased baking dish; pour water around garlic. Cover and bake at 350° for 1 hour or until garlic is very soft. Cool for 5 minutes. Slowly drizzle oil into the center and over each garlic head. Remove soft garlic from skins; spread on bread or over cooked meats or vegetables. Yield: 4-6 servings. With a sharp knife, cut off the top of each head of garlic, exposing the cloves inside. Place in a small baking dish; bake as directed.

3 to 3 1/2 cups Pillsbury BEST™ Bread Flour 2 teaspoons sugar 1/2 teaspoon salt 1 (1/4 oz.) packet active dry yeast

1 cup warm water (120 to 130°F)

2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil

STIR flour, supar, salt and yeast in large bowl. Add warm water and oil. Mix well. Turn dough out onto lightly floured surface. Knead until dough is smooth and elastic, about 10 minutes, adding additional flour as necessary. Coat large bowl with no-stick cooking spray. Place dough in bowl, turning to coat top. Cover toosely with plastic wrap. Let rise in warm place until doubled in size, about 30 to 40 minutes. SPRINKLE baking sheet with commeal. Punch down dough. Shape dough into oval-shaped loaf, about 12 inches long. Place on prepared baking sheet. Coat loaf lightly with cooking spray. Cover loosely with plastic wrap. Let rise in warm place until doubled in size, about 30 to 45 minutes. HEAT oven to 375°F. Make a 1-inch deep lengthwise slash in top of loaf using a serrated knife. Brush loaf with egg white. Bake 30 to 35 minutes or until loaf sounds hollow when lightly tapped. Makes 1 loaf (16 servings)

title: Chun King Casserole
content:
y<sub>2</sub> cup chopped onion V<sub>2</sub> cup chopped celery 1 can (81/2 oz.) Chun King Water Chestnuts, chopped, DRAINED 1 tablespoon oil 1 can (about 7 oz.) tuna, drained, flaked 2 tablespoons minced parsley 1 can (101/2 oz.) condensed cream of celery soup 1/2 teaspoon curry powder V<sub>4</sub> cup light cream or milk 1 can (5 oz.) Chun King Chow Mein Noodles Saute onion, celery and water chestnuts in oil until onion is soft. Add tuna and parsley, stir-fry about one minute. Combine soup, curry powder, cream; stir in tuna mixture and noodles, reserving 1/2 cup noodles. Pour into shallow one-quart casserole or 11/2 gt. casserole. Top with reserved noodles. Bake in oven preheated to 350° for 35 to 45 minutes until crisp and lightly browned. Makes approximately four one-cup servings.

Chow Mein noodles are an important part of oriental menus. Chow Mein is traditionally served over a bed of chow mein noodles; very often noodles are sprinkled on top of chow mein, as well. Crispy, crunchy Chow Mein Noodles are also delicious as snacks, in cookies, or in casseroles.

title: Neiman Marcus Cookie Recipe
content:
NEIMAN MARCUS \$250.00 COOKIE RECIFE A friend of a friend had lunch at the Hedges at Neiman Marcus in November, and for dessert she had a cookie. She thought it was the most wonderful cookie she had ever tasted and asked if the recipe was available. She was told that it was but there was a charge of two-fifty. She said that was fine, got the recipe and told them to just charge her account.

In December when she got her bill, there was a charge of \$250.00. She called and told them there was a mistake. that the charge should be \$2.50. She was told there was NO mistake--that the charge was correct. They told her it was not a returnable item and she would have to pay the amount charged to her account of become delinquent in her payments.

The bottom line is, she paid. She has vowed to get them back, and wants to get the recipe out to everyone she possibly can, and asks that everyone who gets a copy send it to everyone they know. So here it is: 2 cups butter 2 cups sugar 2 cups brown sugar 4 eggs 2 teaspoons vanilla 4 cups flour \*5 cups blended oatmeal. 1 leus poon sal! 2 Ieaspoons baling powder 2 teaspoons baking soda 4 ounces chocolate chips 18-ounce Hershey Bar, grated 3 cups of chopped nuts Blended natmeal; Measure and blend in a blender to a fine powder. Wash chicken breasts well. Pat dry. 2. Combine lime juice, Lea & Perrins White Wine Worcestershire Sauce, oil, oregano, pepper and salt in a glass bowl. Add
chicken and marinate covered for 2 hours, turning twice. 3. Remove chicken from marinade and grill over hot coals, 4 inches from the heat for about 12-15 minutes, turning once and basting with marinade until chicken is cooked through. Do not overcook. 4. Remove chicken to a cutting board and slice into strips 3 inches long by 1/2 inch wide. 5. Lay out tortillas, divide chicken evenly and place in the center of each. title: Finger Foods Guide
content:
Appetizers whet the appetite and hint at the meal to follow. A good beginning to the meal, there should not be too many nor too much. A few appetizers are more appealing than an overwhelming wariety. If foods are to be eaten, serve with beverages for more enjoyment. Includes hors d'oeurves, beverages, or savory food served before a meal.

Appetizers to be eaten as finger foods should be bite-size. If other than fresh vegetables, they should be eaten from a wooden or plastic pick.

Choose complementary flavors for the rest of the meal to keep appetizers tantalizing. Use texture contrasts, color contrasts and a variety of shapes.

To prevent a last-minute rush, prepare some or all before the event.

title: Chocolate-Almond Bars
content:
FILBERT CRESCENTS Tender, rich and nut-crusted cup butter or margarine, softened 3/4 cup packed light-brown sugar 2-1/2 cups all-purpose flour 1/4 teaspoon salt teaspoon grated lemon rind tablespoon lemon juice 2 egg whites, beaten 2 cups finely chopped filberts Pat to about 6" x 4", then turn dough over with still enough sugar on board so that dough does not stick. Pat into 12" x 8" rectangle and cut dough in 2" x 1" bars. Put, separated, on greased cookie sheets and let stand I hour, or until surface is dry and a bit crusty. Bake in preheated 350°F. oven about 10 minutes (middle should be soft and outside crusty). Cool on racks. Makes 4 dozen. Cream butter and sugar until light.
Mix together flour and salt. Add to butter mixture with lemon rind and juice and mix well. Chill several hours, then divide in 6 portions. Shape each portion in a roll 16" long and 1/2" in diameter. Cut in 2" pieces. Dip in egg white, then roll in nuts. Put on greased cookie sheets. Pull ends toward center to form crescents. Bake in preheated 400°F, oven about 10 minutes. Cool on racks. Makes 4 dozen.

title: Salad Recipes
content:
Personally. I hate to make salads. Whenever people ask what they can bring to dinner, I blurt out "salad" without a moment's hesitation. Maybe that's because I'm not so good at making them. My friend Sandi, on the other hand, makes a faller salad. Here are her rules:

- 1. Use a good homemade salad dressing (see recipes).
- 2. Dress the salad in moderation-don't drown the greens.
- 3. Use greens that actually have some. flavor-arugula, spring mix, frisée, spinach, radicchio, máche, watercress and endive.
- 4. Consider contrasts in your saladsweet dried cranberries or raisins with sharp feta cheese, rich walnuts with bright crisp radishes or carrots.
- 5. Actually toss the salad. This way all the ingredients get coated with the dressing. (There's a reason it's called a "tossed" salad.) -Jill Melton

title: Dry Rub Recipes
content:
Dry rubs store on the shelf for 1 to 3 assurabs, depending on the blend of ingredients. Not all ingredients will age at the same rate, so the flavor of the rub may change the longer it is moved. This is one reason why it is bear to prepare small amounts and use them quickly. Rubs are sensitive to light and heat. Keep dry rubs in a home canning jar or plastic murage container and place in a cabinet to protect the rub from light and hear.

The reasoning or flavoring characteristics of a dry rub is givar. Only a small amount. I tablespoon or less, is needed to season a single fish filler, chicken breast or steak. Larger cuts of meat or whole portions of poultry and fish use about 16 cup. Depending on how the dry rub is to be used, there may be some remaining for a second use. To prevent the contamination of remaining rub during initial use, measure only the amount of rub needed for one application in a separate dish.

Rubs are often prepared using fresh ingredients. But many of the same ingredients can be used in their dry state. The time required to airdry fresh ingredients can be minimized using a dehydrator.

title: Zucchini Oven Fries
content:

In a bowl mix together 1/2 cup panko bread crumbs, 1/4 cup shredded Parmesan, 1/8 tsp ground cumin, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp dried oregano, 1/4 tsp paprika and 1 tsp kosher salt. title: Egg Ideas
content:
Eggs are one of your best food buys. And they're so versatile and easy to prepare! For example, a dozen eggs (that's a pound and half of high-quality protein) can feed a family of 6 for less than a dollar. When eggs sell for 75¢ a dozen they're costing you only  $50<sup>4</sup>$  a pound!

**Y'S BEST FOOT** 

And with those dozen eggs you can scramble up a super supper, fry some fantastic egg sandwiches, stir up an easy but elegant quiche or turn out a hearty casserole. Here are some super-fast egg ideas to help feed your family without busting your budget.

Instant Egg Pick-Up: blend an egg, a cup of orange juice and a teaspoon of honey in a blender or shaker jar. Makes a quick and easy breakfast or a super snack. Great for kids, on-the-go moms and dads, anybody.

Egg Taco: Scramble some eggs and spoon into crisp taco shells. Drizzle on taco or hot sauce, then sprinkle with cheese, lettuce, chopped tomato, whatever. Fast to fix, fun to eat, and cheap!

Kangaroo: Halve a piece of pocket bread and open each half to form a pouch. Then scramble eggs with some chopped ripe olives,

title: Nut Lace Cookies
content:
Lasking like roughhewn jewels, Westerncours nots are framed by these grandscule curamel cookies. Thin, crisp, and shiny they make striking desserts or impressive gifts.

Fragile to bite, the cookies are much easier to make and sturdier to handle than they look. The process is simple-but it requires some careful attention.

As the caramel around the nuts bakes, it spreads into a very thin layer 5 to 6 inches in diameter. You can bake only a few cosises at a time.

while hot, the caramel is soft. As it cools, the cookies become rigid. The trick is to get them off the pan after they harden enough not to stretch and tear, but before they get so brittle they break.

Stored airtight, these cookies stay crisp. If you want to make them more than a week ahead, they should be frozen for best flavor. W you're giving them away, handcarry them-very carefully.

To create a striking visual effect and an easier-than-pie desse.t, tuck a cooky vertically into a bowl of your favorite flavor of ice cream.

title: Corn Bread Recipe
content:
Corn Bread (Makes 12 servings) **I cup ALBERS Yellow Corn Meal** cup all-purpose flour 1/4 cup granulated sugar tablespoon baking powder I teaspoon salt 1/3 cup vegetable oil egg, lightly beaten 1 cup milk

**COMBINE** corn meal, flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in medium bowl. Combine oil, egg and milk in small bowl: mix well.

ADD milk mixture to flour mixture; stir just until blended. Pour into greased 8-inch square pan.

**BAKE** in preheated 400°F. oven for 25 minutes or until wooden pick inserted in center comes out clean. Serve warm. **NOTE:** Recipe may be doubled. Use greased  $13 \times 9$ -inch pan; bake as above. For Muffins: SPOON batter into 10 to 12 greased or paper-lined muffin cups filling 2/3 full. title: Creole Pralines
content: **CREOLE PRALINES** 3 cups packed light-brown sugar I cup heavy cream 1/4 cup butter or margarine 2 tablespoons light corn syrup 1/4 teaspoon salt I teaspoon vanilla 1-1/2 cups pecan halves, lightly toasted In large heavy saucepan mix sugar, cream, butter, corn syrup and salt. Bring to boil over medium heat, stirring to dissolve sugar. Set candy thermometer in pan and cook syrup, stirring occasionally, to 234° (soft-ball stage). Remove from heat; let stand 5 minutes. Stir in vanilla and pecans. Beat with spoon until mixture begins to thicken and loses its gloss. Drop by 1/2 tablespoonfuls onto waxed paper and spread to form patties about 2 inches in diameter. Let stand until firm, then wrap individually in plastic wrap. Store in airtight containers in cool dry place. Makes about 1-3/4 pounds.

title: Pastry Techniques
content:
Cakes may be divided into two classes-Butter and Butterless or Sponge. A good Butter cake should be fine grained or of smooth texture. This is obtained by accurate measuring and skill in combining ingredients which require effort and time. The butter should be creamed until light colored. Fine granulated sugar should then be blended well with it. Eggs should be separated and well beaten before adding.

Dry ingredients should be sifted before and after measuring and these should be added alternately with the milk to the butter, sugar, and egg mixtures. Beaten egg whites and flavoring should be then folded into batter. Butter cakes require a moderate oven-350 to 400 degrees Fahrenheit. Sponge cakes require a slow oven-275 to 350 degrees Fahrenheit. Sponge cakes contain little liquid but great amounts of egg. Angel cake is a type of Sponge cake. Do not grease pans for sponge cakes. Frost cakes after they are cold.

Frosting should be cold when put on.

Skill is required in making good pastry. Flakiness, crispness and tenderness are characteristics of good pastry; and these are realized by the selection of good ingredients, accurate measurements and skillful mixing.

Pastry should not be made in a warm temperature.

Shortening should be worked in with a blender.

Ice water is conducive to tender pastry,

title: Fried Green Tomatoes
content:
thick Salt 1 egg, beaten Yield: 4-6 servings.

3 medium green tomatoes, sliced 1/4 inch

1/4 cup cornmeal 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese 2 tablespoons all-purpose flour 3/4 teaspoon garlic salt 1/2 teaspoon dried oregano  $1/8$  teaspoon pepper 1/4 cup vegetable oil

Lightly sprinkle tomatoes with salt; drain on paper towels for 30-60 minutes. Meanwhile, combine cornmeal, Parmesan, flour, garlic salt, oregano and pepper in a shallow plate. Dip each tomato slice into egg, then into cornmeal mixture. In a medium skillet, heat oil over medium-high. Fry tomatoes, a few at a time, for 2 minutes per side or until golden brown. Drain on a paper towel-lined wire rack. Serve immediately.

title: Simple Syrup Recipe
content: **SIMPLE SYRUP** Combine 11/2 cups granulated sugar and 11/4 cups water in saucepan. Stirring occasionally, bring mixture to boil over medium-high heat. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes. Remove from heat; cool in pan. Refrigerate in glass jar up to 1 month. Makes about 2 cups. **BLACKBERRY LIQUEUR Gently** wash 3 cups fresh blackberries; dry on towels. Place blackberries in glass container with tightfitting lid. Wash, dry, and remove peel from 1 lemon, scraping any white pith from peel. Add lemon peel to blackberries. Using wooden spoon, gently mash blackberries and peel. Add one 750-milliliter bottle vodka; stir and seal jar. Place in cool, dry spot away from sunlight. Let sit 2 weeks, swirling occasionally. Add 1% cups Simple Syrup (see recipe above). Stir again; reseal. Let sit 2 more weeks. Strain liqueur through double layer of 100% cotton cheesecloth into pitcher. Strain again through

title: Greek Lemon Cake
content: This feathery cake is lovely served with ice cream or fresh fruit marinated in a liqueur. 3 cups cake flour or 2-3/4 cups all-purpose flour 1 teaspoon baking soda 1/4 teaspoon salt 6 eggs, separated 2 cups sugar, divided 1 cup butter or margarine, softened 2 teaspoons grated lemon peel 2 tablespoons lemon juice 1 cup plain yogurt Stir together flour, soda and salt; set aside. In large bowl of mixer beat egg whites until soft peaks form. Gradually add 1/2 cup sugar, beating until stiff but glossy peaks form; set aside. Beat butter, remaining 1-1/2 cups sugar, egg yolks, lemon peel and juice until fluffy. Stir flour mixture alternately with yogurt into creamed butter mixture, then gently fold into egg-white mixture. Pour into greased 10-inch plain or fluted tube pan. Bake in preheated 350° oven 50 to 60 minutes or until pick inserted in center comes out clean. Cool in pan 10 minutes, then turn out on rack to finish cooling. Serves 12.

title: Oriental Soup Recipe
content:
You'll find other kitchen-tested recipes in the latest issue of **Better Homes and** Gardens® magazine.

**Nograph Mike Jensen** 

Our tasty Oriental soup makes the most of a calorie-cutting secret: reducing fat. It uses a homemade chicken stock that's been skimmed of fat, which contains 9 calories per gram. You save 100 calories for every tablespoon of the or oil you trim  $-$  and you still can enjoy full flavor. Try it today!

**Chicken Stock** In a Dutch oven place backs, necks, and wings from 2 chickens; 2 large stalks celery. cut up: 2 carrots, cut up; 1 large onion, cut up; 2 sprigs parsley; 1 bay leaf; 1/2 teaspoom dried thyme, crushed; 2 whole cloves; 1/2 teaspoon salt; and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Add 6 cups water. Bring to boiling; reduce heat. Cover and simmer 11/4 hours. Remove chicken; strain stock by pouring through a colander or sieve lined with a double layer of cheesecloth. Discard solids. Clarify stock, if desired. If using stock hot, skim off fat. Or. chill for 6 to 8 hours and lift off fat. Makes 51/2 cups.

4 cups Chicken Stock

content:
